title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance to People Affected by Unrest in Syria

description.narrative:
According to the 2016 Humanitarian Needs Overview, 13.5 million people in Syria are in need of various forms of humanitarian assistance, of which 8.7 million people, or one in three Syrians, require food assistance. The situation is most grim in besieged and hard to reach areas where approximately 4.5 million people are subjected to partial or complete movement restrictions and have been cut off from regular humanitarian assistance for months or, in some cases, years. In these areas, estimates suggest that more than half the population, 2.5 million people, including almost 500,000 people in 18 besieged locations, are severely food insecure, with some at risk of starvation.
The recent agreement at the Munich conference amongst the International Syria Support Group (ISSG) members to cease hostilities in the country and facilitate the implementation of UNSCR 2254 gives hope to the humanitarian actors operating inside the country. During this conference, seven of the eighteen besieged areas were identified as priority locations (Kafr Batna, Moadamiyah, Madaya, Zabani, Foah, Kefraya, Deir Ezzor city) that urgently need life-saving food assistance in order to save the 350,000 civilians living in these locations from starvation.
In light of this agreement, WFP is appealing for a USD 2 million HPF grant in order to provide the civilians living in the seven priority besieged locations with an enhanced food basket in recognition of their food security status and the access challenges. The HPF grant will allow WFP to procure 1,267.37 mt of chickpeas and Plumpy Doz, which will be used to complement the general food basket, so that 70,000 families are provided with a food basket containing 2,100 kcal for a period of three months. WFP aims to distribute the enhanced food baskets for three months to the 350,000 civilians in need who are living in the seven priority besieged locations, based on the assumption that regular accessible will become available. However, the implementation of the proposed activities is subject to approval from the relevant authorities to access the afore-mentioned locations. Therefore, quantities will be prioritised to all besieged locations, whenever access becomes available. Should access to besieged locations fail to materialise, WFP will evaluate the possibility of redirecting the quantities to respond to sudden displacements and surges in humanitarian needs in other parts of the country, particularly in hard to reach locations.
